verse.name: v1
verse.lines: Susanna Martin was a witch who dwelt in Amesbury With brilliant eye and saucy tongue she worked her sorcery And when into the judges court the sheriffs brought her hither The lilacs drooped as she passed by And then were seen to wither

verse.name: v2
verse.lines: A witch she was, though trim and neat with comely head held high It did not seem that one as she with Satan so would vie And when in court when the afflicted ones proclaimed her evil ways She laughed aloud and boldly then Met Cotton Mather's gaze

verse.name: v3
verse.lines: "Who hath bewitched these maids," he asked, and strong was her reply "If they be dealing in black arts, ye know as well as I" And then the stricken ones made moan as she approached near They saw her shaped upon the beam So none could doubt 'twas there

verse.name: v4
verse.lines: The neighbors 'round swore to the truth of her Satanic powers That she could fly o'er land and stream and come dry shod through showers At night, twas said, she had appeared a cat of fearsome mien "Avoid she-devil,"they had cried To keep their spirits clean

verse.name: v5
verse.lines: The spectral evidence was weighed, then stern the parson spoke "Thou shalt not suffer a witch to live, tis written in the Book" Susanna Martin so accused, spoke with flaming eyes "I scorn these things for they are naught But filthy gossips' lies"

verse.name: v6
verse.lines: Now those bewitched, they cried her out, and loud their voice did ring They saw a bird above her head, an evil yellow thing And so, beneath a summer sky, Susanna Martin died And still in scorn she faced the rope Her comely head held high
